metadata.title: Novel Immunoglobulin Domain Proteins Provide Insights into Evolution and Pathogenesis Mechanisms of SARS-Related Coronaviruses

abstract.text: A novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) is the causative agent of an emergent severe respiratory disease 20 in humans that is threatening to result in a global health crisis. By using genomic, sequence, 21 structural and evolutionary analysis, we show that Alpha-and Beta-CoVs possess several novel families 22 of immunoglobulin (Ig) domain proteins, including ORF8 and ORF7a from SARS-related coronaviruses 23 and two protein groups from certain Alpha-CoVs. Among them, ORF8 is distinguished in being rapidly 24 evolving, possessing a unique insert and a hypervariable position among SARS-CoV-2 genomes in its 25 predicted ligand-binding groove. We also uncover many Ig proteins from several metazoan viruses 26 which are distinct in sequence and structure but share an architecture comparable to that of CoV Ig 27 domain proteins. Hence, we propose that deployment of Ig domain proteins is a widely-used strategy by 28 viruses, and SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 is a potential pathogenicity factor which evolves rapidly to counter the 29 immune response and facilitate the transmission between hosts. 30 31

body_text.text: Nidoviruses are an ancient group of lipid-enveloped viruses with non-segmented RNA genomes, which 35 are known to infect oomycetes and animals, including molluscs, arthropods and vertebrates (1) . Among 36 them are the coronaviruses (CoVs) which possess the largest known monopartite RNA genomes and are 37 classified into four genera-Alphacoronavirus, Betacoronavirus, Gammacoronavirus, and 38
Deltacoronavirus (2) . Over the past two decades, Beta-CoVs, including the viruses responsible for 39

Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in 2003 and Middle Eastern Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) in 40 2012, have emerged as significant local land global health concerns with economic consequences (3, 4) . 41

Recently, a novel severe respiratory disease has emerged in humans (abbreviated COVID-19) (5, 6) . 42 COVID-19 presents with a relatively long incubation period of 1-2 weeks followed by development of 43 fever, dry cough, dyspnea and bilateral ground-glass opacities in the lungs (7) . In some patients, this can 44 proceed to fatal respiratory failure, characterized by acute lung injury (8) and acute respiratory distress 45 syndrome (9) . Within several months of the first outbreak, there have been over 75,000 confirmed cases 46 with over 2,000 deaths of COVID-19 globally (https://www.who.int/docs/default-47

The host-pathogen arms-race has selected for a disparate complement of viral genes involved in 127 pathogenesis. These genes often rapidly diversify through recombination and mutations to keep up with 128 the evolution of host resistance. To identify proteins with potential pathogenic roles in COVID-19, we 129 conducted a comparative genomic analysis of the coronaviruses. Similarity plots show that the bat CoV 130

RaTG13 is the closest relative of SARS-CoV-2 with no evidence for recombination between them ( Figure  131 1 and Figure S1 ). SARS-CoV-2 also shows good similarity to two other bat viruses, CoVZXC21 and 132
CoVZXC45, first in the 5' half of ORF1 and again after nucleotide number 20,000 of the genome. 133

However, the remaining part of ORF1 of SARS-CoV-2 and RatG13 show no specific relationship to these 134 viruses. This suggests a recombination event between the common ancestor of SARS-CoV-2 and RaTG13, 135 and probably another member of the SARS-related clade close to CoVZXC21 and CoVZXC45. In addition 136 to this major recombination event, we identified several smaller regions which might have undergone 137 recombinational diversification during the emergence of the SARS-CoV-2 genome ( Figure S1 ). Notably, 138 many of them are clustered in three regions displaying extensive diversification, corresponding to the N-139 terminal region of the ORF1a polyprotein, the Spike protein, and the uncharacterized protein encoded 140 by ORF8 (Figure 1 and Figure S1 ). 141 142

Among these three fast-evolving proteins, we focused on the ORF8 protein as it is one of the so-called 144 accessory proteins, which does not participate in viral replication (32, 33), raising the possibility that it 145 might have a role in viral pathogenesis. body_text.text: The homology model of ORF8, based on the structure of SARS-CoV ORF7a (pdb id:1XAK), suggests that 161 this insert augments a potential peptide-ligand binding groove that has been proposed for ORF7a 162 ( Figure 2B and Figure S3 ). Hence, the emergence of the insert has gone hand-in-hand with the 163 acquisition of a modified interaction interface. 164 165 Besides these families, we identified a fourth family of Ig domains from the same Alpha-CoVs which 166 contain the above-discussed ORF7a/8-like Ig family ( Figure 3A ). These Alpha-CoVs typically possess one 167 or two paralogous copies annotated as either ORF4a/b or NS5a/b. From their sequences, these Ig 168 domains are not closely related to the ORF7a and ORF8 Ig domains ( Figure S4 ). However, profile-profile 169 searches have shown that they are related to Ig domains found in the adenoviral E3-CR1 proteins 170 (probability: 90% of matching the Pfam CR1 Ig domain profile) ( Figure S4 ). In these searches, they also 171 yield weaker hits to two other Ig domains, namely the poxviral decoy interferon receptors and human T-172 cell surface CD3 zeta ( Figure S4 ). 173

body_text.text: Phylogenetic analysis of ORF7a, ORF8 and Alpha-CoV Ig domains shows that each group represents a 176 distinct clade ( Figure 2C ). The tree topology of ORF7a mirrors that of the polymerase tree ( Figure 3A) ; 177 however, the topology of the ORF8-Ig clade is not consistent with it. This might be due to a 178 recombination event between the SARS-related CoVs (as suggested by the similarity plot analysis) 179 and/or unusual divergence under selection. To better understand the functional difference between 180 ORF8 and ORF7a, we examined the column-wise Shannon entropy in the 20 amino acid alphabet and 181 found that the ORF8 has significantly higher mean entropy than ORF7a (ORF8: 1.09 vs ORF7a: 0.22, p< 182 10 -16 for the H0 of congruent means by t-test) ( Figure 2D ). By comparing column-wise entropies in both 183 the 20 amino acid and a reduced 8-letter alphabet (where amino acids are grouped based on similar 184 side-chain chemistry), we found at least 14 positions in ORF8 which show high entropy in both alphabets 185 as compared to a single position in ORF7a ( Figure 2D ). This indicates that ORF8 is a fast-evolving protein 186 under selection for diversity as contrast to ORF7a. Strikingly, one of these highly variable positions, 187 which features residues with very different side characters (hydrophobic, acidic, alcoholic and proline), 188 corresponding to Leu84 was also identified as the most variable position across 54 closely related 189 human SARS-CoV-2 genome sequences (38). body_text.text: The presence of multiple Ig domains with different affinities in CoVs prompted us to more generally 215 survey animal viruses for Ig domains. By using the Pfam models (39) and our own PSSMs created from 216 PSI-BLAST runs with Ig domains (12), we were able to identify about 17 distinct viral Ig domain families 217 in a wider diversity of animal viruses ( Figure 3B and Table S2 ). In addition to CoVs, such Ig domain 218 proteins can be found in adenoviruses, NCLDVs, Herpesviruses and Phenuiviruses. These viral Ig domains 219 are highly divergent; many of them are only found in certain viral groups. However, the majority have an 220 architecture comparable to the CoV-Ig domains, with an N-terminal signal peptide, one or multiple Ig 221 domains and a C-terminal TM region often followed by a stretch of basic residues. Thus, although the Ig While ORF8 is a paralog of ORF7a, its lack of the TM segment, unique insert and significantly more rapid 247 evolution suggest that it has acquired a distinct function and has been under strong positive selection 248

body_text.text: One possible mechanism is that, like the adenoviral CR1 proteins, it interferes with MHC molecules to 249 attenuate antigen presentation, resulting in ineffective detection of the virus by the host immune 250 system. Consistent with this, the SARS-CoV ortholog translocates to the ER (48) and its higher variability 251 indicates probable selection due to its interaction with a rapidly evolving host molecule. ORF7a is a known member of the 151 immunoglobulin (Ig) domain superfamily and is specifically related to extracellular metazoan Ig domains 152 that are involved in adhesion, such as ICAM (35, 36). The Beta-CoV ORF8, ORF7a and the Alpha-CoV Ig 153 domains display a classic β-sandwich fold with seven β-stands and share the characteristic pattern of 154 two cysteines which form stabilizing disulfide bonds with metazoan Ig domains(Figure 2AandFigure S2) 155 (37). However, they are unified as a clade by the presence of an additional pair of conserved disulfide-156 bonding cysteines(Figure 2A). Nonetheless, there are notable structural differences between the three 157 groups of proteins. ORF8 is distinguished from ORF7a and Alpha-CoV Ig proteins by the loss of the C-terminal transmembrane (TM) helix and the acquisition of a long insert between stands 3 and 4 with a 159

FIGREF1.text: domain proteins are newly acquired in subsets of Alpha-and Beta-CoVs 196 We examined the distribution of CoV Ig proteins in the context of a phylogenetic tree of both Beta-and 197 Alpha-CoVs based on their polymerase proteins (Figure 3A). Other than the two subsets of Beta-CoVs 198 and Alpha-CoVs that contain the above-described Ig domain proteins, no other CoVs contain any Ig 199 domain proteins (Figure 3A). The immediate sister-groups of the Ig-containing CoVs typically have Spike, 200 E, M and N, and one or two other uncharacterized accessory proteins which are not Ig domains to our 201 best knowledge. The Alpha-CoV ORF9/10 share a C-terminal TM helix and, along with ORF7a of the Beta-202 CoVs, lack the insert in the Ig domain (Figure 2A). Hence, it is possible that this architecture represents 203 the ancestral state which was present in the common ancestor of both Alpha-CoVs and Beta-CoVs. 204 Under this scenario, the protein was displaced/lost both in certain Alpha-CoVs and Beta-CoVs. 205 Alternatively, ORF7a could have been exchanged between Alpha-and Beta-CoVs by a recombination 206 event. In both scenarios, ORF8 arose likely via a duplication of ORF7a in specifically the Beta-CoVs. 207 Although we couldn't identify the ultimate precursors of the CoV Ig domains, they are likely to have 208 been acquired on at least two independent occasions from different sources. FIGREF2.text: favor the emergence of larger RNA genomes in CoVs (40). Indeed, this might have also 225 contributed to the acquisition of potential pathogenesis factors such as the Ig domains described herein 226 which are comparable to those seen in DNA viruses. 227 228 Novel CoV Ig domain proteins are potential immune modulators 229 Why have diverse viruses independently acquired the Ig domain during their evolution? First, the Ig 230 domains are major mediators of adhesive interactions in both eukaryotes and prokaryotes (37, 41, 42). 231 Thus, this domain can be used for adherence for cell to cell spread (e.g. herpesviral Ig domain proteins) 232 (43). Further, Ig domains are major building blocks of metazoan immune systems. Thus, viruses often 233 utlize this domain to disrupt immune signaling of the host. For example, in adenoviruses, the CR1 Ig 234 domain proteins have been shown to block the surface expression on infected cells of class I major 235 histocompatibility complex molecules by blocking their trafficking from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) 236 to Golgi (44). This has been shown to affect the host inflammatory response and modulates the 237 presentation of viral antigens to T-cells (45). In poxvirus, the secreted Ig domain proteins function as 238 interferon receptors or decoys that bind the interferon-α/β and disrupt signaling via the endogenous 239 host receptors (46). Further, SARS-ORF7a has been implicated in the interaction with bone marrow 240 stromal antigen 2 (BST-2), which tethers budding virions to the host cell in a broad-spectrum antiviral 241 response, to prevent the N-linked glycosylation of BST-2 thereby crippling the host response against the 242 virus (47). This suggests it might still fold into an intact structure held by 256 the two disulfide bonds formed by four conserved Cys residues. 257 258 In conclusion, the presence of fast-evolving ORF8 Ig domain proteins in the SARS-related viruses, 259 including the emergent 2019 SARS-CoV-2, suggests that they might be potential pathogenicity factors 260 which counter or attenuate the host immune response and might have facilitated the transmission 261 between hosts.
